Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Score-Based Observation Versus Imaging in Early Equivocal Appendicitis

Trial_Design.evidence: single-centre randomised controlled trial included adults with suspected appendicitis

Participants.evidence: adults with suspected appendicitis, symptoms for less than 24 hours, and an Adult Appendicitis Score (AAS) of 11–15

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to imaging or observation groups

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if early imaging results in more diagnoses of acute appendicitis than initial observation

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the number of patients requiring treatment for acute appendicitis within 30 days

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: using computer-based block randomisation with allocation concealment via a web-based system

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between May 2016 and March 2020, 185 patients were randomised: 93 to imaging and 92 to observation

Number_Analysed.evidence: After exclusions, 93 and 88 patients were analysed, respectively

Result_Outcome.evidence: 72% required treatment for appendicitis compared to 57% in the observation group (odds ratio 0.51, 95% CI 0.27 to 0.95; p = 0.032)
